doc_id: Anonymous - 1660 - By the merchants owners of ships and mariners, trading to His Majesties sugar-plantations_page_2.xml
text:
BY THE MERCHANTS
OWNERS OF SHIPS AND
MARINERS, TRADING TO.
His MAJESTIES Sugar-Plantations.
IT is humbly offered to the Consideration of this Honourable House, That the white
Sugar Planters, by an Accompt untruly stated; delivered by them to the Committee
of the House of Lords, they doe Assent that unpurged brown Sugars doe produce cleare
of Charges to the Merchant above Nineteen shillings and nine pence each hundred
weight, whereas it is most true, and is ready to be made appeare by exact Accompts, of
the Sale of that sort of Sugars which came from Barbadoes, to the hands of severall
Merchants of good Credit the last year, that they doe not produce above Eleven
shillings a Hundred, and some not above Ten Shillings; and the Planters themselves
in their said Accompt, Rating white Sugars but at Fifty Shillings per Hundred,
which is Ten Shillings under their just and Indifferent value, do make them to produce
Thirty nine Shillings per Hundred, which is near four for one; And it is ready
to be made appear, that several parcels of white Barbadoes Sugar, have been lately
sold at Seventy four and Seventy six Shillings per Hundred by an Eminent white
Sugar Planter, at which Trice they produce above five to one.
And it is farther humbly Proposed, that if it shall Please this House to reduce the
Rate of unpurged Brown Sugar to half a farthing per pound, his Majesty will thereby
receive a Greater and more Certain Revenue, then by Imposing one farthing per
pound on the said Sugar, forasmuch as at a half farthing per pound, all or the
greatest part of the unpurged Sugars, that shall be Imported from his Majesties Plantations
will be Refined, and Consumed in this Kingdom, and his Majestie will receive
the full Excise thereof, as well as of White; when as Paying one farthing per
per pound the Refiner cannot be encouraged to Manufactor them; and being for
noe other use, they must be Exported to Forreign Markets, whereby His Majestie will
not onely lose the whole duty of Excise, but also half of the Customes Inwards, which
will be Returnable upon the Exportation, and so the Manufacture will be wholly lost
to this Kingdom; And Forreign Nations will reape the Sole Benefit thereof.

entities.text: Committee of the House of Lords
entities.label: ORGANIZATION
